Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Can avoidance behavior and landscape complexity explain patterns of predator coexistence in mammalian carnivores?
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores the population dynamics of large African predators, asking how spotted hyenas, leopards, and cheetahs are able to live with lions, given that lions frequently harass and kill these smaller predators. Investigators will integrate data from surveys of lions with data from camera traps to determine how hyenas, leopards, and cheetahs distribute themselves across the landscape with respect to lions, and how differences in habitat use enable these species to coexist with and without lions. Understanding how predators coexist is important for understanding how large ecosystems function. Recent research has emphasized the profound effects that top predators can have on ecosystems; disrupting predator populations can destabilize natural systems in unexpected ways. The ability to predict how and why destabilization occurs is a necessary first step to preventing the ecological collapse of ecosystems with many types of predators. This project will engage the public through a citizen science platform (www.SnapshotSerengeti.org) in which members of the public help identify wild animals in photographs taken by camera traps. As anthropogenic change drives the continued decline of large predators around the world, research on ecosystem stability becomes increasingly relevant, as does public engagement in research.

More specifically, this study will test predictions from an ongoing predator study in the Serengeti by comparing distributions and population sizes of spotted hyenas, leopards, and cheetahs across two South African reserves with and without lions. For example, without lions, leopard numbers may higher or hyenas may occupy prime riverine habitats. This type of response is expected because overlap between mammalian predators is typically minimal; instead, suppression appears to be mediated primarily through direct aggression and a large-scale avoidance response that displaces subordinate species from large portions of the landscape. In traditional predator-prey systems, this non-consumptive effect (NCE) of predation risk creates a "landscape of fear" that can be more important for predator-prey dynamics than actual predation. It can, for example, be the driving force behind trophic cascades. However, the role of NCEs in driving population dynamics has been almost exclusively investigated in small scale predator-prey systems. This project investigates the role of NCEs in driving apex-mesopredator coexistence in a guild of large African carnivores. The research has two aims: (1) to compare effects of large-scale displacement in driving lion-mesopredator coexistence, and (2) to evaluate the role of landscape structure and behavioral avoidance at multiple spatial and temporal scales in mediating lion-mesopredator coexistence. It is predicted that complex landscapes will facilitate fine-scale partitioning and thus coexistence by minimizing large-scale displacement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Disrupting relationships within predator guilds can have cascading effects in communities and destabilize natural systems. Thus, there is a clear need to develop a predictive understanding of how predators coexist. Animal behavior – especially avoidance strategies that limit an animal’s access to resources -- can play a pivotal role in driving such dynamics, but these behavioral mechanisms have only been studied extensively in small-scale systems, experimental systems, typically with invertebrates.

This NSF DDIG project evaluated behavioral and environmental characteristics driving patterns of coexistence among large African carnivores. The overarching aim was to develop a generalizable mechanistic understanding of how large predators coexist in ecosystems around the world.

This project leveraged existing long-term research in Serengeti National Park, Tanzania, and across a series of managed game reserves in South Africa. Our primary goals were to collate, process, and analyze existing data from large scale camera trapping surveys in these different reserves into a comparative analysis to explicitly test the role of a) lions as a top predator, and b) habitat structure in mediating predator coexistence.

To address these questions, we first had to develop new approaches for processing and analyzing the existing camera trapping data.  Camera trap surveys provide a powerful tool for simultaneously monitoring multiple species across large areas, but produce enormous quantities of imagery that must be classified by species and numbers of animals present. The www.snapshotserengeti.org website that we launched in 2012 demonstrated enormous potential for citizen science to produce useable, expert-quality data. During this NSF DDIG, we analyzed Snapshot Serengeti volunteer classifications and user behavior and developed general guidelines to make citizen science an effective tool for research. We collaborated with the citizen science platform www.zooniverse.org to build web tools so that other research teams can build their own interfaces. In combination, the analytical approaches and web tools will allow other research teams to engage volunteers in image processing for ecological research. We are now in the process of building a “Snapshot South Africa” website to process the camera trap images collected from South Africa. 

We additionally developed new methods for analyzing camera trap data to reveal fine-scale spatial and temporal avoidance among large predators. Using these methods, we found that cheetahs avoid lions on a moment-to-moment basis, thus maintaining access to both habitat hotspots as well as their prey. Such fine-scale avoidance may be a key mechanism for predator coexistence. These results have been presented at two ecological conferences and are currently being written up for publication.

This project establishes new methods to continue exploring community dynamics for long-lived, wide-ranging species. This project also actively engages the broader public in this research through the www.snapshotserengeti.org project where members of the general public can help identify the animals and behaviors photographed in the camera trapping survey. As anthropogenic change drives the decline of large predators around the world, the research questions addressed here become increasingly relevant, as does engaging the public in research designed to understand the natural world.
